comments.commentBody: It's stories like this that make me wonder why anyone believes that Government run Universal Healthcare will be run any better.

There are two dangerous conclusions some quick readers may make from this article:
1. That innocent looking people CANNOT be terrorists, and
2. That since the government might make mistakes they should do away with the 'watch list'.
The reporter should know well that the media makes errors all the time - except the retractions appear on page 44 rather than on page 1. That's the luxury of the media!!! This type of sensational journalism is what is bringing down the image of the NY Times - not that of the governments efforts to protect us.

This story explains perfectly why US security has so many problems: underwear bombers need only misspell their names to get themselves through security. Meanwhile, the TSA wastes lots of time ensuring that two-year-olds and elected officials such as Ted Kennedy (he wasn't the only one) aren't trying to get us. If a person at the check-in desk can figure out these mistakes and roll her eyes, why can't the TSA? Does anyone in security officialdom actually *think*? Could we please follow the Israeli example here? And maybe make some adjustments in our foreign policy and the way we treat prisoners in Guantanamo, etc?

OK, so Mikey is on the "selectee" list and he gets stopped and searched every time he travels. Presumably it's not because of his family of origin, since his parents aren't subject to the same scrutiny.

Then we have the underwear bomber, who should be on the absolute STOP list because he's known to have been consorting with terrorists in Yemen, his family had warned the US embassy, the UK had already rescinded his visa because of terrorist ties, he had bought a one-way ticket with cash, he had checked in for the flight with no luggage, and yet he waltzes through security and gets on the plane with his explosives.

Something wrong with this picture.
Nice to know that they upset the Anglos as much as the non Anglos. Other wise you would never know what humiliations we suffer. We too are Americans, but we reflect light of a different wavelength.
The treatment isn't going to be any better as he gets older; something needs to be done now.

http://www.familylinks.icrc.org...

Family Links at the Red Cross website

How does this work exactly? I think we have found proof that at least 45000 Americans will do anything to be distracted into not thinking ... I think the number is greater

I suppose if I was a Packers fan and Revis had won, I'd be howling that his loudmouth coach had bought it for him.

A simple case of advocacy.

I will say that the 2:1 margin in first place votes was hard to ignore. It definitely sent the message: "The stats that show up in the box score next to your name are the only ones we consider."

Hey, with the stat-freak nature of certain followers of this sport, I have no doubt we are on the cusp of a new era in how we measure the effectiveness of cornerbacks. Rex seems pretty convinced that few men in history have had the season Revis had, and Rex wants us to consider some other stats in support of that.

He may have something.

how wonderful then that CURIO, *such* a non-yiddishism, is the fill for it. and how wonderful that this puzzle is sooooo lively -- caleb's youth and the active minds of his elderly students apparently complement each other very well. that's some kinda synergy!

bravi --

;-)
I could get only one answer, Italia.

We just got back from Istanbul today and we wanted to write a review.Alstar AMBASSADOR got positive reviews on NYC, and I'm pleased to say that for the most part the stay was very good.

The location cant be beat. You are about 5-10 minutes from all the big sites, and a main tram station to go anywhere beyond that. There's heaps to do and lots of spots for a coffee, tea, or a meal. There's even a Starbucks within walking distance, great for all of you coffee drinkers I'm sure if we mentioned it to the staff they would have taken care of it. But we returned so exhausted each day we didn't want to deal with a repair guy or potential room switch,

The staff is very nice, and quite helpful. The ride to and from the airport is a great convenience, even for 25 euros. If you book via their site they will pick you up for free. They also have perks like a free breakfast and wifi with great speeds (8 megs).

In the end, I would definitely stay here again if I went back to Istanbul. Recommended
(The staff of Ambasador hotel was extremly helpful, polite and professional. When it was the birthday of my friend the reception kindly offered to buy a cake for my friend and helped me to make a nice surprise. :)))

Very fun puzzle. I flunked Yiddish, thought Tchotchke was a character on Kotter or maybe Happy Days. "Lets go" for ITSAGO slowed me down. I thought the theme was great. And, I love the idea of some senior coming up with Paris' catch phrase.

I don't see how you get an abbreviation on a song, Beatles or otherwise. Maybe on the record? Or the sheet music? But on-a-song seems very strange.

I want to take the class. Is there a correspondence course?

To Old Leatherneck:
I am an female ex-nco, and I would be happy to compare fitness with your sorry self any day - both "then" and "now". There are, and always have been, slackers on both sides of the gender line. Gross generalizations like yours are not useful and may indicate your mental fitness never caught up with your biceps. Get a grip.

calories in > calories burned = fat

troops in combat zones and REMF's fed by contractors (Halliburton, Brown and Root) on cost plus no bid contracts = +++ calorie, low nutrition diet = maximum profits

"eat all that you can eat" builds fat soldiers, sailors, flyers, and Marines

The old timers are right.
The Army changed its physical fitness standards in 1999 to a much more relaxed PT Test. It essentially did make it easier to score higher by reducing the max level of push-ups and sit-ups and by raising the time required to max the 2 mile run.
Check it out.

this video is not supporting Taliban, it just condemns the illegal arresting of innocent Pakistani people by US agencies, barbaric jails Guantanamo Bay & Drone Attacks.
it also tells current chaos state created in Pakistan by US agencies.
Fair point. We should have picked this up. No excuses.

Now for a little mental fitness.  Please learn the difference between "than" and "then."  Then is used to connote time.  Than is used to connote a comparison between two things.  The author uses "then" incorrectly twice.

I can't speak for the other services, but as was mentioned before, the Marine Corps takes physical fitness and appearance very seriously. In addition to the Physical Fitness Test, consisting of the traditional pullups, crunches, and a 3 mile timed run, the Combat Fitness Test was recently introduced as a way to measure the fitness of Marines in a combat like scenario. A 880 yard sprint in boots is followed by 30-35 lb ammo can lifts and ending in a "maneuver under fire" where the individual Marine is forced to sprint, crawl, pickup up a wounded comrade and carry him or her a certain distance and still be expected to have the strength to carry two ammo cans to the end of the course and back. The PFT and CFT scores are factored in evaluations and promotions and those not seen as up to par are quickly dealt with. Physical appearance is also seen as important to the image the Marine Corps. Those Marines that do not meet the height/weight standards or consistently under-perform physically, are assigned to the Body Composition Program and Military Appearance Program. The BCP was designed to get Marines back to an acceptable physical fitness level and appearance or separate them from the Corps. Commanders have the authority to assign Marines to the program even if they meet the height/weight standards if they simply look out of shape. So do I think Marines are more out of shape now than they were in the past? No. Careful oversight by unit commanders and solid guidance from the Commandant on issues of appearance and fitness ensures that the vast majority of the Marine Corps remains more than capable of both joining the fight and looking sharp in a set of Dress Blues.

'The military' encompasses a wide range of services with a corresponding wide range of physical requirements. I remember a staff NCO who did duty with the Royal Marines, and he said that they ran him into the ground as he developed knee problems. Friends who were in Reconnaissance said that they were humping fools, as did a neighbor who was in the Special Forces. They're a much smaller force so they can have more stringent training requirements.

http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Marines

....The Royal Marines have one of the longest basic infantry training courses in the world..... all Royal Marines, except those in the Royal Marines Band Service, complete the Commando course as part of their training (see below). Key aspects of the course include climbing and ropework techniques, patrolling, and amphibious warfare operations.

This intense phase ends with a series of tests which have remained virtually unchanged since World War II. Again, these tests are done in full fighting order of 32 lb (14.5 kg) of equipment.

The Commando Tests are taken on consecutive days and all four tests must be successfully completed within a seven day period; they include;

A nine mile (14.5 km) speed march, carrying full fighting order, to be completed in 90 minutes; the pace is thus 10 minutes per mile (6 min/km or 6 mph).

The Endurance course is a six mile (9.65 km) course across rough moorland and woodland terrain at Woodbury Common near Lympstone, which includes tunnels, pipes, wading pools, and an underwater culvert. The course ends with a four mile (6 km) run back to CTCRM. Followed by a marksmanship test, where the recruit must hit 6 out of 10 shots at a 25m target simulating 200 m. To be completed in 73 minutes (71 minutes for Royal Marine officers). Originally 72 minutes, these times were recently increased by one minute as the route of the course was altered.

The Tarzan Assault Course. This is an assault course combined with an aerial confidence test. It starts with a death slide (now known as The Commando Slide) and ends with a rope climb up a thirty foot near-vertical wall. It must be completed with full fighting order in 13 minutes, 12 minutes for officers. The Potential Officers Course also includes confidence tests from the Tarzan Assault Course, although not with equipment.

The 30 miler. This is a 30 mile (48 km) march across upland Dartmoor, wearing full fighting order, and additional safety equipment carried by the recruit in a daysack. It must be completed in eight hours for recruits and seven hours for Royal Marine officers, who must also navigate the route themselves, rather than following a DS (a trained Royal Marine) with the rest of a syndicate and carry their own equipment.

....Completing the Commando course successfully entitles the recruit or officer to wear the coveted green beret but does not mean that the Royal Marine has finished his training. That decision will be made by the troop or batch training team and will depend on the recruit's or young officer's overall performance. Furthermore, officer training still consists of many more months.

Training to be a Royal Marine takes 32 weeks. The last week is spent mainly on administration and preparing for the pass out parade. Recruits in their final week of training are known as the King's Squad and have their own section of the recruits' galley at Lympstone.
